Definition at line 36 of file MPlane.h.

template<typename _Vec >
bool MPlane::GetRayIntersect ( float &  rayMu,
const _Vec &  rayOrigin,
const _Vec &  rayDir 
) const [inline]

_Vec must have a conversion to type MVec defined.

find the distance between the ray's origin and the plane.

if the distance is very close to zero, then the ray originates on the plane; the origin is also the intersection.

find the angle between the ray direction and the plane normal.

if the angle is very close to a right angle, then the ray is parallel to the plane; does not intersect.

solve for the length of the hypotenuse of the triangle formed by the ray's origin, the ray's origin projected onto the plane, and the intersection point.

indicate an intersection point was found.

Definition at line 148 of file MPlane.h.

template<typename _Vec >
bool MPlane::GetSegmentIntersect ( _Vec &  pt,
const _Vec &  pt0,
const _Vec &  pt1 
) const [inline]

_Vec must have a conversion to type MVec defined.

essentially, we're finding how much of the line resides on one half of the plane, and how much of the line resides on the other half. I then use that to find a ratio that I then use to interpolate between the two points passed in.

both points are on the same side of the plane; does not intersect.

find the ratio of how much of the line resides on opposite sides of the plane.

indicate an intersection point was found.

template<typename _Triangle , typename _Vec >
void MPlane::SplitTriangle ( const _Triangle &  tri,
_Triangle *  posTris,
_Triangle *  negTris,
unsigned int &  posCount,
unsigned int &  negCount,
float  epsilon 
) const [inline]

splits a triangle. structure passed in must have vars pt0, pt1, pt2.

determine how many points are on which side of the plane, and how many triangles need to be created.

check to see if the triangle even collides with the plane.

if we have two verts on one side, we'll have two tris on one side, one on the other. note that the maximum number of triangles we can possibly get back is 3.

determine which segment is entirely on one side of the plane.

create the new triangles ( and preserve winding order ).

single triangle on one side.

two triangles on the other.

single triangle on one side.

two triangles on the other.

split the segments that cross the plane.

create the new triangles ( and preserve winding order ).

single triangle on one side.

two triangles on the other.

single triangle on one side.

two triangles on the other.

split the segments that cross the plane.

create the new triangles ( and preserve winding order ).

single triangle on one side.

two triangles on the other.

single triangle on one side.

two triangles on the other.

we only need to split a single edge.

split edges 1 and 2.

split edges 2 and 0.

split edges 0 and 1.
